criteria: Application of Theorems to Parallel Lines and Transversals
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of geometric theorems related to lines and angles.
Student demonstrates minimal understanding of geometric theorems. Struggles to recall or apply basic definitions.
Student demonstrates some understanding of geometric theorems but requires prompting to apply them in proofs.
Student demonstrates a good understanding of geometric theorems and can apply them in simple proofs with some guidance.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding of geometric theorems and can apply them effectively in most proofs.
Student demonstrates excellent understanding of geometric theorems and can apply them effectively and independently in complex proofs.
Student is unable to construct logical arguments or proofs related to lines and angles.
Student struggles to construct logical arguments and proofs, with significant errors in reasoning.
Student can construct simple proofs with significant gaps in reasoning or justification.
Student constructs proofs with mostly sound reasoning but may have minor gaps in justification or logical flow.
Student constructs well-reasoned proofs with clear justification, demonstrating a strong understanding of logical connections.
Student constructs rigorous and elegant proofs with impeccable reasoning, demonstrating mastery of logical deduction and justification.
Student does not demonstrate knowledge of theorems related to parallel lines cut by a transversal.
Student struggles to identify and apply theorems related to angles formed by parallel lines and transversals.
Student can identify some angle relationships but struggles to correctly apply theorems in problem-solving.
Student applies theorems related to parallel lines and transversals with some accuracy, but may make minor errors in calculation or justification.
Student consistently and accurately applies theorems related to parallel lines and transversals to solve problems.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of angle relationships and theorems, applying them creatively to solve complex problems involving parallel lines and transversals.
Student demonstrates no understanding of perpendicular bisectors and their properties.
Student struggles to define or identify perpendicular bisectors and their relationship to equidistant points.
Student identifies perpendicular bisectors but struggles to apply the theorem relating them to equidistant points.
Student applies the perpendicular bisector theorem with some accuracy, but may struggle with more complex problems.
Student accurately applies the perpendicular bisector theorem to solve problems, demonstrating a clear understanding of its properties.
Student demonstrates a thorough understanding of the perpendicular bisector theorem, applying it effectively in a variety of geometric contexts and problems.
